qas.question: Who followed in Johnson's footsteps in terms of ensuring equal opportunity?
Which piece of legislation was begun in 1969?
Which industry of jobs did the legislation target?
Aside from the construction industry, which other group was one of the main offenders against equal opportunity laws?
Who held the position of Assistant Secretary of Labor?
Who followed in Johnson's footsteps in terms of ensuring unequal opportunity?
Which piece of legislation was ended in 1969?
Which industry of jobs did the legislation not target?
Aside from the construction industry, which other group was one of the main offenders against unequal opportunity laws?
Who held the position of Secretary of Labor?

context: The strides that the Johnson presidency made in ensuring equal opportunity in the workforce were further picked up by <a0_0>his successor <b5_0>Nixon<b5_0/><a0_0/>. In 1969 the Nixon administration initiated the "<a1_0><b6_0>Philadelphia Order<b6_0/><a1_0/>". It was regarded as the most forceful plan thus far to guarantee fair hiring practices in <a2_0><b7_0>construction<b7_0/><a2_0/> jobs. Philadelphia was selected as the test case because, as Assistant Secretary of Labor <a4_0><b9_0>Arthur Fletcher<b9_0/><a4_0/> explained, "The <a3_0><b8_0>craft unions<b8_0/><a3_0/> and the construction industry are among the most egregious offenders against equal opportunity laws . . . openly hostile toward letting blacks into their closed circle." The order included definite "goals and timetables." As President Nixon asserted, "We would not impose quotas, but would require federal contractors to show 'affirmative action' to meet the goals of increasing minority employment."
